intro: Ligusticum elatum, commonly known as the giant chervil, is a tall, herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes parsley, carrots, and celery, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and umbel-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows to heights of up to 2 meters, with slender stems and a delicate, aromatic fragrance. Its flowers are usually white or pale yellow, and it blooms in late summer to early autumn. Ligusticum elatum is often found in rocky or gravelly soils and is adapted to high-altitude environments.
